abstract: Apple is likely to make so much money from its cut of iPhone usage fees that it can sell the product at a loss and still make money.
snippet: Apple is likely to make so much money from its cut of iPhone usage fees that it can sell the product at a loss and still make money.
lead_paragraph: Apple is likely to make so much money from its share of iPhone usage fees paid to wireless phone companies that it can sell the product at a loss and still make money. It can even cover the cost of its $100 rebates to people who bought the phone before it cut the price to $399.

headline.main: Losing Money on the iPhone and Making It Up on Volume

abstract: Experts said a European antitrust ruling might signal problems for companies like Apple, Intel and Qualcomm.
snippet: Experts said a European antitrust ruling might signal problems for companies like Apple, Intel and Qualcomm.
lead_paragraph: LUXEMBOURG, Sept. 17 — Europe’s second-highest court delivered a stinging rebuke to Microsoft Monday, but the impact of the decision upholding an earlier antitrust ruling may extend well beyond the world’s largest software maker to other high-technology companies.

headline.main: Microsoft Ruling May Bode Ill for Other Companies
headline.print_headline: EUROPEAN COURT FAULTS MICROSOFT ON COMPETITION

byline.original: By Kevin J. O'Brien and Steve Lohr

abstract: Steve Jobs, Apple’s chief executive, said the iPhone would become available to British consumers in November in an exclusive arrangement with O2.
snippet: Steve Jobs, Apple’s chief executive, said the iPhone would become available to British consumers in November in an exclusive arrangement with O2.
lead_paragraph: LONDON, Sept. 18 — Apple brought the iPhone to Europe today, hoping to entice consumers with a sleek design and the iconic power of the Apple brand even as it flouts some of the technological and marketing conventions of the European mobile phone business.

abstract: Apple will offer the iPhone in Britain with free access to 7,500 WiFi hot spots to compensate for a weak data network.
snippet: Apple will offer the iPhone in Britain with free access to 7,500 WiFi hot spots to compensate for a weak data network.
lead_paragraph: Apple announced its deal to offer the iPhone in the United Kingdom in a deal with O2, a unit of Spain’s Telefonica, as expected. The one surprise is that it has arranged for iPhone users to get free access to a WiFi network called The Cloud. This is largely to compensate for the spotty coverage of O2’s data network using the Edge technology in the iPhone. At the event in London earlier today, Steve Jobs, Apple’s chief executive, repeated his assertion that the iPhone doesn’t use faster 3G technology because the drain on the phone’s battery is too high.

headline.main: The Cloud Over the British iPhone
